text: Anyone know why I am getting a `You don't have permission to connect this integration.` While just using the contacts scope? What right do I need to access the contacts API, because I would think almost anyone can use the contacts API

Hey, <@UNY3W0UQ2>. Usually the property itself will be named in the error message.

Can you share your Hub ID, the request URL being used (without the `hapikey`), and the full error message?

Hey, <@UJA612KEE>. The easiest way to avoid this is to use a _Super Admin_, but if this isn’t feasible or preferred, the user must have full access to all contacts, companies, and deals. Per this article (<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/oauth2/initiate-oauth-integration>), the `contacts` scope grants access to all three objects, so the user must also have access to all three.

Here are some screenshots of what a non-Super Admin’s permissions might look like.
<@UDDJG2VFG> Thanks for helping me out! I figured out my payload was actually `properites -> properties -> array` instead of a single level `properties` value.
Aha! Yep, that would do it :sweat_smile:
Hey
Sorry to "interrupt".
What you "really" need is EXACTLY this + access to "lists" (it's in the "marketing" tab)
Not sure why every HubSpotter I talked to about this keep saying that you need superadmin (or access to basically everything) in order to do this.
<@UDDJG2VFG>, any ideas about this? Who is in charge of reviewing/correcting the KB article that mention that you need superadmin access?

Hey, <@ULSCN5SSW>. Good question. You don’t _need_ Super Admin access, but a Super Admin will always be able to install an integration. If a customer is encountering “You don’t have permission to connect this integration” errors, the quick fix is to have a Super Admin do it. The alternative is to list out every permission and make sure the user in question checks all boxes. As such, HubSpotters often opt for the former, although it may not be as technically accurate.

yeah, but as I mentioned before (not to you, but to everyone i talked about this). this is like going to buy an ice-cream, get your credit card  denied for lack of funds and the operator telling you that you need one million dollars in your account in order to buy the ice-cream (or like i told David Adams, your cart doesn't start in the morning and when you call your insurance they tell you " oh, you need a full fuel tank to stat your car" )

Support responds that as if it was an absolute truth and i get they do that because that's what you can read here <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/kcs_article/integrations/resolve-a-request-for-integration-permissions-error>
it gets even more frustrating when it's also the dev advocates that ones that quote that same stuff :cry:

at this point i'm trying to find who i should talk to about this so we can change the KB article and change the support script (i guess the two go together), because even this may not seem important, it's actually hurting my business as the "oh, you HAVE TO be superadmin"  response some of my prospects are getting is directing many of them to just decide not to proceed with testing the app (because they cant /wont get superadmin rights to their users)
if you could help me with this i would owe you big time! :pray:

Just to clarify what should read on the KB article, you dont need " all boxes checked"  to get access to the contacts scope, you ONLY need view/edit owned and unassigned contacts+"lists". In the old days, users running Free Crm or Sales/Services Starter had to be superadmin (because they didnt have the marketing tab, hence no way to  enable "lists")

Thanks for the feedback,<@ULSCN5SSW>. I agree the language in that knowledge base article could be softened and clarified; I’ll work with the team who owns that doc to improve it. That said, the solution you’re describing only applies to apps requiring  the `contacts` scope [group] alone. There are many other combinations of scopes and user permissions which can throw the “You don’t have permission to connect this integration” error, and it’s not possible to document them all.

i understand. This actually works for " timeline"  too, as "oauth, contacts & timeline"  are the ones we use. The issue here is that when emailing those contacts that filled the form to try our product and then never used , a few times we got a "we tried to connect, got the error message and and learned that users had to be superadmin so we wont be interested in your product" , or even worse " we reached out to support and they told me..."

even when this is clearly explained in our support page, prospect receiving a permissions error hardly ever get there because they can read a " hard answer" from the HubSpot screen :disappointed:

Yeah, I’m sorry to hear that :confused: I think I may suggest something like:
> To resolve this type of error, the user connecting the integration must have full read and write access to the objects and settings an integration uses. For instance, if an app requires the `contacts` scope, a user must have full access to contacts, companies, deals, and lists. Integrations have varied requirements, so we recommend referencing a given app’s documentation. Learn more about changing a user’s permissions (<https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/articles/kcs_article/settings/edit-user-permissions>).
> If you are still encountering errors after following an integrator’s documentation, please contact support for assistance.
> Finally, Super Admin roles have every permission an integration may require. In select circumstances, a Super Admin may need to connect an integration.
the thing is that you dont need full access to contacts
<https://files.slack.com/files-pri/T22MX8Z8B-FP05H78AE/image_from_ios.jpg>
